[[Orderic Vitalis]] wrote that in the year [[1130]], Ãengus with [[MÃ¡el Coluim mac Ãeda]] (or ''[[MacHeths|MacHeth]]'') invaded ''Scotia'' with 5000 warriors. The Moravians were met by David's general, an old [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] noble named [[Edward Siwardsson]]. The [[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle]] reported "a great slaughter" .<sup>2</sup> The Annals of Ulster tells that 4000 Moravians were killed, and only 1000 Albanians.<sup>3</sup> The ''Annals of Innisfallen'' makes clear what Orderic Vitalis said, that the battle took place in "[[Scotland]]", and was hence an invasion. <sup>4</sup> Siward defeated the Moravians and Ãengus was killed. The royal Scottish army invaded Moray, which, as Orderic Vitalis puts it, "lacked a defender and lord."<sup>5</sup>
[[Orderic Vitalis]] wrote that in the year [[1130]], Ãengus with [[MÃ¡el Coluim mac Ãeda]] (or ''[[MacHeths|MacHeth]]'') invaded ''Scotia'' with 5000 warriors. The Moravians were met by David's general, an old [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] noble named [[Edward Siwardsson]]. The [[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle]] reported "a great slaughter" .<sup>2</sup> The Annals of Ulster tells that 4000 Moravians were killed, and only 1000 Albanians.<sup>3</sup> The ''Annals of Innisfallen'' makes clear what Orderic Vitalis said, that the battle took place in "[[Scotland]]", and was hence an invasion. <sup>4</sup> Siward defeated the Moravians and Ãengus was killed. The royal Scottish army invaded Moray, which, as Orderic Vitalis puts it, "lacked a defender and lord."<sup>5</sup>
â
Why did Ãengus invade? Was he pursuing his own claim against David, or was he pursuing a MacHeth claim? We simply do not know. What we do know is that the 1130 invasion led to the (re-)incorporation of the Moravian kingdom into Alba. It was probably regranted to [[William fitz Duncan]], and after his death in [[1147]], was colonized by David's French, Flemish and English followers, although in the longer term, most of these were Gaelicized.
+
Whether Ãengus invaded to pursue his own claim against David or to purue a MacHeth claim is unknown. However, the 1130 invasion resulted in the (re-)incorporation of the Moravian kingdom into Alba. It was probably regranted to [[William fitz Duncan]], and after his death in [[1147]], was colonized by David's French, Flemish and English followers, although in the longer term, most of these were Gaelicized.
